feed.title: Combined summary - Bug in 2-of-3 transaction signing in Bitcoind?

entry.title: Combined summary - Bug in 2-of-3 transaction signing in Bitcoind?
entry.summary: This context involves a Bitcoin transaction that attempts to redeem a 2-of-3 multisig P2SH output using a raw transaction. The transaction is signed with 2 out of 3 keys, but it is rejected by the network upon transmission without any clear indication of why or what error occurred. Inputs provide information on the source of funds, while outputs give details on where the funds are being sent and in what amount.On April 15, 2014, Mike Hearn sent an email to the Bitcoin-development mailing list regarding a rejected transaction. He suggested checking the debug.log for the reason behind its rejection. It was found that the first input was spent by another transaction that closely resembled it. Mike recommended version 0.9 of Bitcoin should report more detailed reasons for rejections. The email also contained a link to a free O'Reilly book called "Graph Databases". In the same email thread, Mike Hearn advised using btcd, the Go implementation of bitcoind because it had better error/diagnostic messages than the original implementation. Additionally, Matt Whitlock discussed a tool he and his team built in C++ that performs key and address conversions, hash functions, encoding and decoding, script disassembly, BIP38 encryption/decryption, the Shamir Secret Sharing, transaction building and signing. They were testing this tool by sending Bitcoin to multi-sig P2SH addresses from public seeds, then finding them in the blockchain to create transactions that redeem them which they sign with private seeds. The tool is easier to use than Bitcoind and can be run with simple command-line syntax.Furthermore, a person who posted a message on the Bitcoin-development mailing list apologized after realizing that the debug.log already stated that the inputs were already spent. Pieter Wuille responded to the post saying that the first input appeared to have already been spent by a similar transaction. Mike Hearn suggested checking the debug.log to find out why the transaction was rejected. In addition, an advertisement for a book called "Graph Databases" was shared in the email thread.It appears that a transaction has been accepted into the blockchain 15 blocks ago, despite there being issues with getting anything to accept the transaction. However, it is unlikely for the transaction to be accepted again as it would be considered double-spending. It is important to thoroughly review all available information and resources in order to properly diagnose and address any problems when dealing with Bitcoin transactions.
